venue.name: Harvard Museum of Natural History, Geological Lecture Hall

item.description:
The Evolution Matters Lecture Series at the Harvard Museum of Natural History is back for 2012.   Join us as Iain Couzin presents a lecture entitled From Democratic Consensus to Cannibalistic Hordes: The Principles of Collective Behavior.

From the HMNH website:

Why do billions of locusts suddenly break into motion? How do ants carry heavy loads and march with orderly precision along densely packed trails?  How do flocks of birds and schools of fish select their navigators? And how do we—humans—make decisions as citizens, drivers, and numerous other social situations? Iain Couzin, Assistant Professor of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Princeton, has made major contributions to understanding the dynamics and evolution of collective animal behavior.

The lecture is at 6:00, at the Geological Lecture Hall, 24 Oxford St., in Harvard Square.  It's free and open to the public.  We'll meet beforehand inside the building, outside the entrance to the lecture hall, between 5:30 and 5:45 (Doreen will be there earlier, John may straggle along later since he doesn't have a T-compatible job).  If you miss us, just go on in, and afterwards we'll congregate in the same place, then go out for food and drinks somewhere in the Square. We'll both be wearing our nerdy Meetup pins :)

There's free parking at the 52 Oxford St. Garage, and of course there's a Red Line stop right there in Harvard Square.

Hope to see you there :)

http://www.hmnh.harvard.edu/lectures-classes-events/evolution-matters-2012.html

52 Oxford Parking Garage Map
item.how_to_find_us: Look for John or Doreen with a nerdy Meetup pin, near the inside entrance to the lecture hall
item.name: Evolution Matters Lecture Series: The Principles of Collective Behavior
